conversation.content: Um, hi, I just got my bill and it's, uh, it's three times what it usually... I don't understand what's...
Oh, um, I'm so sorry to hear that's—let me just—actually, can I get your account number first? It should be, uh, at the top of your bill, starts with ACC.
ACC-4982. Look, I'm a single mom, I can't afford this.
Okay so, um, I'm pulling up ACC-4982 here and, uh, oh wow, I see what you mean about the increase, that's—I'm really sorry, that must be, um, really stressful.
Can you just, um, tell me why it's... what's the word... why it jumped like that?
Right, so I can see here that your usage for billing period BIL-2024-03 shows 2,847 kilowatt hours which is definitely—I mean, that's significantly higher than your average.
But we didn't do anything diff— um, I mean, nothing changed, so how is that even...

I understand, I really do, and um, sometimes there can be—actually, let me check—okay so I'm seeing meter reading MR-73921-X was done on the 15th, and uh, it looks like they had been estimating your bills before.
Estimating? So they just, um, guessed wrong and now I'm... of course. Of course this happens.
Yeah, um, I know this is—look, I'm really sorry about this, but basically when they do actual readings after estimates, sometimes there's a, uh, catch-up adjustment in billing cycle CYC-4982-Q3.
A catch-up? That's just... fantastic. Really great.

I can hear how frustrated you are and, um, honestly? I think it's—I mean, the system shouldn't work this way, it's not fair to customers, especially when you're budgeting and then suddenly get hit with adjustment ADJ-9982-7.
Um, so what am I supposed to, uh, actually do here? I literally can't pay this.
Okay, so—and I really want to help you here—um, we have a payment plan option, reference code PAY-PLAN-88K, where we can spread this over, uh, I think up to six months?
Six months of... and then next month's bill too, so that's, um, that's still...
Right right.
I just, um, don't understand how they can just, uh, estimate wrong and then I'm the one who...

No, you're absolutely right, and um, between you and me? I see this happen way too often with meter corrections like COR-4421-B, and I always feel terrible because—I mean, how are people supposed to plan for this?
Exactly. Um, the payment plan, is there a... what's it... a fee for that?

So, um, actually—and this is some good news at least—there's no fee for plan enrollment PLE-7736-X, and uh, I can even backdate it to avoid any late charges, which, um, technically I'm supposed to get supervisor approval for but honestly, given what happened here with the estimates...
